element_texts.text: From Guada. to Guanaxuato  June 2nd - I left Guada. this morning at about 5 o'clock, - accompanied only by a Servant with a Cargo mule, on my way to Guanaxuato to attend to some very disagreeable law affairs which called me there, and of which I shall afterwards give an account. --  I had tried all I could to avoid this journey, but every interception made for me by His Majesty's charge d'affaires & Consul General in Mexico to prevent my being obliged to to proceed to Guanaxuato.

myself put to further inconvenience and expense, but there was no remedy, and the hopes of meeting with better treatment from my prosecutors in Guanaxuato, gave me some encouragement to pursue my journey contentedly in the expectation of having a speedy conclusion to my sufferings in so unjust a Cause. --  July 26th.  However, here I still am, nothing done with me or my Case as yet, and shut up

was unavailing, so on giving Security for my appearance (which W. Ritchie had the kindness to do for me ) I was allowed to go alone. --  Set out, however with a sad heart; - I had been put to the greatest possible inconvenience already for the Same Account, had been at very considerable expenses, and had received the most brutal treatment from the authorities of the State of Calisco. --  With no good will did I see

of the greatest strikeout: advantage importance and with what I have seen of the Country, and my long residence in it, I ought to have been able to give a tolerably good and correct account of many important places and circumstances, which no traveller has yet mentioned, but the want of a regular note book, ported daily, obliged me to draw completely on memory for any thing I may now state. I shall

in a large room in a Militia Barracks of this city since the 8th inst.- -  I have often thought that the many books that have been written about Mexico, do not give So full an account of the Country but what there is still much left to write about, and many false statement to correct. --  The great advantage of keeping notes and strikeout: I writing down daily what one sees, is

from Mexico and about 80 from the Port of San Blas on the Pacific. --  From various points strikeout near the city, it has an elegant appearance, I may even say a splendid one, but on entering the streets the illusion is lost completely. All the Suburbs are composed of low houses built of unburnt brick here and there one of them plastered over and

begin with my journey from Guadalaxara to Guanajuato but it perhaps would be as well to say something about the former city in the first place, so before setting out, I shall do my best, and give as full a description of it as I can. --  The City of Guadalaxara is situated in the middle of an extensive plain, about 140 leagues W.N.W  Pop 45,000 Guanajuato 60,000

the tout ensemble rather a disagreeable appearance.  No regard whatever has been paid to uniformity of height in fact, it seems as if they had tried to make the houses as unequal as was in their power. --  The streets are almost all at right angles with one another, and the plan of the city (on paper) on this account, makes a

whitewashed, but generally they show the bare brick walls, which gives them a most rueful aspect. --  Towards the Centre, there are some very good streets, altho' very far from elegant with respect to buildings: - the houses being almost all built of adobe or unburnt brick, and some whitewashed, Some painted one color Some another, gives to

its exterior is not very attractive, yet its situation in the Centre of the City on one Side of the principal square makes it catch the eye. --  The building is extensive and the late improvements certainly have adorned it very considerably. During the last four years it has been undergoing a thorough repair interiorly and exteriorly and in the courses of another twelve

very neat appearance. --  The city on the whole, is rather neat than otherwise and as regards size and importance is the second in the Republic, seat of the Supreme Government of the State of Xalisco, a bishoprick, "Comandancia general," and contains a great many splendid churches and colleges. &c. --  Among the Public buildings the Cathedral is one of the most Conspicuous;--altho'

They are still about 100 feet high, but make a very awkward appearance. The interiour is undergoing a complete change and Certainly will combine a degree of splendour and elegance perhaps not to be found in any one of the Churches in the Country. --  Adjoining the Cathedral, and making a very neat appearance are the many offices

month it is expected to be finished.  A handsome dome, surrounded by an elegant stone balustrade has just been finished, and all that is now wanting to make it a very beautiful edifice is the finishing of the towers or steeples.  They were thrown down by an earthquake in the year 1818 and have never been rebuilt. --

The building is large, occupying a whole square, and contains within its walls, the Governor's apartments where he resides, the different Courts of Justice, the Senate, State treasury, government offices, the offices of the government of the Canton of Guada. the Principal, and the Prison,--besides dwellings for some of the empleadas. The Ayuntameinto hold their sittings at a house

of tythe gatherers, record keepers &c. --  On the east side of the Principal square, stands the Palace, a dull heavy stone building, with some pretension to ornamental architecture, but to antiquated, and contrasting to it with the broken windows and shabby woodwork of them, that what might once have been an ornament is now rather the contrary --

expulsion was seized by the Government. --  It is now fitted up as a College, and the plan of it does honor to D. Prisciliano Sanchez the late Governor, -whose strikeout: premature untimely death however has retarded considerably the good effects to be expected from an institution of this sort, and which would do honor to any Country. -- The Lancasterian school.

16  on the street on the north side of the Palace, also dignified with the name of palace, as it serves also for the Congress hall until the splendid one preparing for them be ready to receive them.  The instituto, occupies one side of another square one street distant to the west of the principal one.  It was formerly the Convent of the Jesuits, and on their

19  Confer the greatest honor on strikeout: W Jones this gentleman. -- -- the drawing department is taught by a Spaniard and a Native of the place, and is very ably conducted in its own way. --  It certainly is a unclear that such abilities as are shown by many of the pupils which are indeed wonderful shown the confined to the drawing of heads, hands &c. as if they were all intended to be portrait painters. --

18  which composes the first seccion of the Instituto is taught by W. Richard Jones, son-in-law of the famed Joseph Lancaster. --  The class room is an elegant apartment, capable of containing 400 boys with ease. This department and the progress made strikeout: will by the pupils, together with the strict, yet gentle discipline maintained by W. Jones, certainly

Soon after Commencing it, saying that it is too difficult: --  the Master is no great proficient himself and I daresay he finds it his interest to frighten his scholars out of the study of a language which he would have some difficulty in teaching. -- Mathematics and Mechanics are also taught by a frenchman.  The other departments are filled by the natives of

20  In the other departments, are taught Medicine, Surgery, Materia Medica &c. by a frenchman, strikeout: said to be well qualified for his situation: -- The french & English languages, by another Frenchman, who altho' he has always a few disciples in French, Can never keep any one  long at English: --  they generally leave off the study of the latter language very

What was formerly the chapel of the Convent, is now fitting up as a Hall for the State Congress--The interior exceeds any thing of unclear in the Country in the richness and beauty of its ornaments and gilding but is rather too fine for the strikeout: place intended for the S solemnity which ought to attend the meetings and deliberations.

of the Country. --  Chemistry by an ignorant apothecary who may perhaps know enough of to enable him to mix a glass of Soda water, but I am sure he cannot tell you he why nor the wherefore it should be Sodawater. --

25  The front when finished will be a great ornament to the City, but the building now stopped for want of funds.-- Vertical note left margin into text: May 1832--building going on and the columns are at full height, and are most elegant. The massive and elegant grecian columns, intended to form the peazza in front, have stood now upwards of a year, raised only to the height of about fifteen feet, and very likely will continue until a change of the government

of the representatives of the people.--It is too gaudy, and with the addition of an altar, a few paintings and an organ in one of the galleries would make a splendid chapel, and it is not altogether unlikely that it may yet be again turned to this purpose, if the clergy are allowed to go on as they are now Carrying every thing before them.--

27  he has the means--They are strikeout: both built strikeout: and by strikeout: one two of the late Bishops of the See of Guadalaxana, and are institutions which it is impossible to look upon without sighing and regretting that all ecclesiastics should not be the Same Sort of man as the founders of these two splendid establishments. The first of them is well endowed and the absolute necessity

26  and some more worthy and public spirited man fill the place of the unprincipled scoundrel who is now at the head of the State Government against the will of every body and strikeout: ag in contrariety to the votes and Suffrages of the people. --  The "Hospicio de Pobres" or Poor house, and the Hospital, are monuments of the much that a good man may do when

29  persons of all Sorts. and I believe the place will go to ruins before it is even finished. --  There is a small cotton spinning mill set up in one part of it, which altho' only about 2 years since finished is already abandoned and going to wreck for want of a director. --  There is a university and college, governed both by

28  of keeping the hospital open for the use of the sick prisoners and soldiers, has not allowed the rapacity of the ruling clergy to seize upon the funds belonging to it, as they have done with those of the Hospicio.  In the latter there is a sort of show kept up also, of maintaining and educating about sixty poor boys and girls, altho' the place is large enough for 1500

31  There are in all the city churches, and it is divided into parishes. --  The Bishop's palace, now that the See is Vacant, is hired out to families, and the low apartments Contain the offices belonging to the Cabildo. --   Next to the Bishops Palace is the Mint, an elegant new building, and well distributed. -- W. Murray, who was

30  the clergy of whom all the teachers are Composed, which contain about 800 students, who are taught bad latin, grammar strikeout: and what they call Philosophy, Theology & jurisprudence.  There are many Convents and what are termed colleges for the education of females, where they are taught reading and needlework. Convents both of friars and nuns are very abundant, there being in all of the former and of the latter.

33 about 600 people of both sexes in the making of Segars, who gain on an average about two dollars a week. --  The Penitentiary for Females is more of a convent and is annexed to one of the Parish Churches. The principal occupation of the prisoners is cooking for the prisoners of the public jail who sometimes amount to the No. of 1000 --

32  treasurer and director of the Mint, and to whom the establishment is indebted for the flourishing condition in which it now is, was lately disciplined from his situation by the present governor for no other reason than his being an Englishman! after having Served the house 20 years. --  The tobacco Manufactory is another new and elegant building, and employs

38  canal supported by 8 or 10 neat arches of about 15 feet span and afterwards is allowed to run down again to its former level below ground from whence it goes to the different fountains in the city, with airholes in every three or four streets. --  Before the revolution an extensive building was erected in the suburb of Mexicalcingo with complicated and curious

34  Guada. is well supplied with water by an uncommon aqueduct which comes from a hill about three leagues south of the town. --  I do not know if I am right in calling it an aqueduct, as it courses below ground the whole way till it enters the town, where at one place the water is raised by the natural force of it to a height of about 40 feet, runs along a narrow strikeout

37  erected for the purpose I have mentioned. --  Almost every house is supplied with a well about 60 to 90 feet deep, and the water of those in the strikeout: east west strikeout: of the half of the town is preferred to that of the fountains, while that in the east quarter is never used for drinking or culinary purposes.-- I have seen in Guada, some of the

36  machinery for raising the water to a greater height and strikeout filtering it, but from what cause I do not know, the building only was finished and I believe the Machinery never completed. --  Upwards of $150,000 were spent upon it, and to any argument made to people about it, the only information to be got is that it is called the Fabrica, and was

39  who resort there to walk and for which the place is well fitted, being surrounded by seats, and with a good pavement skirted by trees which however are still small the larger old ones having been rooted out about 5 years ago, on account of the roots destroying the pavement.--Very often one may meet with a double string of half a dozen young ladies

38  women with small wens? on buches? , but they occur very seldom & they are attributed always to some impurity in the water.--
In the centre of the principal square is a very handsome fountain which is constantly playing.--On moonlight nights the plaza has a very gay appearance from the number of people

41  The Alameda of Guada. has never been very fine and on account of its having been so much neglected for a long time, now that it has been Unclear a little more order and is pretty tolerable very few people use it as a promenade.  It is very neatly laid out, and has some very handsome trees, which according

40  with an elderly gentleman and lady bringing up the rear, as in families where there are brothers, they generally prefer taking their pleasure by themselves to accompanying their sisters and unless Some other young Lady be of the party to whom he can give his arm, he never takes the trouble of accompanying those of his own family.

43  very gay appearance from the number of carriages, and equestrians.  of the former sometimes upwards of 100 are on the paseo at once, among which now and then can be distinguished two or three English & American Carriages, Curricles and gigs -- The men on horseback sometimes have splendid dresses in the Country

42   to our ideas of gardening are much handsomer from the manner of their being planted,--irregularly, and not in straight lines as is the Spanish fashion generally.--The paseo extends, south from the alameda along the side of the river for about a mile, and on Sunday afternoons and holidays has a

45  Guada. on a great holiday strikeout fills the public walks in a very elegant manner. --  By an act of Congress bull fighting was for ever prohibited in the State of Calisco, but the legislature of 1829 found means to get the word "puntales" (sharp horned) inserted after the word "toros", so that the law only says

44  Fashion, and Guada. is famous for the manufacture of the different articles of which the curious and elegant suit is composed. --  The horses are in general very beautiful animals, and most of the handsomest in Mexico come from the neighborhood of this city. --  The women are prettier too than those of Mexico, so that

47  but as he lost in the speculation, no one else has had strikeout: en courage to venture on it again.  The attempt at all events has proved that the taste for bullfighting has decayed, and the $6000. were given to the Managers of the Theatre to assist them, as their funds were in a low state.

46  that bulls with sharp horns cannot be fought, which is exactly the Same as if the law had never passed, the horns points having been always cut off before turning them into the bull-ring. --  The plaza was let for $6000 for one season and the person who hired it built at his own expense a very neat amphitheatere with boxes, galleries &c.

49  and 1827, there seemed to be a mania for writing for the Stage in Guada and a good many original pieces as well as translations were represented.  Young's Revenge, Lillo's George Barnwell, and Kotzebue's Adelaide of Wulfingen were translated by a friend of mine as exercises in the English Language and were all well received more particularly the last, on account of the attacks it contains on the

48  The Theatre is small, but although the exterior of it has a very shabby appearance, it is very neatly fitted up inside, and the performances are generally pretty good. --  Last year 1830-31, it had the best companies in the Republic both for comedy tragedy and Opera. --  Every person who has been in Mexico, must recollect the sweet singing of Amada Plata. --  In Guada. in the years 1826

51   who received his education in England. --  The poor players were however meanly stoned of the stage, as the audience one and all took it as a Caricature upon their manners -- I myself translated Lillo's fatal Curiosity which was very highly applauded and continued to be a favorite. --  I had began to translate Douglas, but left it off at the end of the first act.

50  Roman Catholic Church priests and the pope. --  It used to produce threats from the Cabildo every time that it was announced for representation, and lately the Church party has been in such power all attempts to bring it forward have been impossible.--"She Stoops to Conquer" was translated and altered to bring the scene near to Guada and suited to Mexican Customs and scenery, by a Gentleman

52    of the former San Pedro about a league distant on the Mexico road is the most frequented, and balls very well attended as kept up almost every night during the greatest part of Sept. and October.  San Andres, Zapopan, Temasaque and a variety of other towns and favorite places of strikeout resort.--in Temasaque are some mineral hot baths. --  Guada. is almost completely surrounded by orchards.

52   Cockfighting is carried out to a great extent in Guada. and a large Cockpit has been newly erected close by the Theatre. --  There are a great many small towns and villages in the vicinity of Guada. which are resorted to in particular seasons of the  year as places of amusement, Some of them as residences for a month or six weeks at a time and others on the days of their patron Saints.

55  Colima, but I believe with the exception of these & perhaps a very few more, it might produce any thing. --  In the Summer months before the Commencement of the rainy season in May and June the Thermometer gets as high as 94º in the shade, and even during the rains when the air is cooler, it seldom falls lower than 80º, and ranges from

54    and gardens which are Capable of producing almost all the fruits both of the table land and of tierra Caliente, but for many of these it depends on the strikeout greater industry of Aguas Calientes, Colima, Zapotlanejo and other places.  There are some fruits which the climate is not warm enough for, such perhaps as the pineapple and Cocoa most which are bought from

57  of which there are nine in the Centre of the town.  They serve as lounges, and shelter from the sun and rain, and are much superior to anything of the kind in Mexico and besides serve all purposes of the Parian. --  There are some very handsome shops and good apartments generally are to be met with of all kinds of European and

56   that to 90º. --  I never have seen it fall lower than 40º. in the very coldest weather. and only for about a month strikeout:12 words in the year do you meet with a day now and then when it strikeout: gets falls so much.  Almost all the dry good shops are confined to the Portales

59  it is covered. --  Another of the portales is filled with ladies and children's shoes of all stuffs and colors, and scattered unclear the rest are stalls of trinkets &c. Some of them very rich. --  The Plaza de San Agustin is fitted up something in the style of the Parian in Mexico, but the articles sold are principally of the manufacture of the

58  Asiatic manufactures, besides those of the place. --  In one of the portales, spread out on Mats on the floor every Variety of fruit is to be found, -- in another is a range of stands for sweetmeats or Conserves of Calabasa or Calabasate (for which the Convent of Santa Maria de Gracia is famous all over the country) makes a very pretty show, from the silver leaf with which

61  general very well supplied and the rates are cheap, and living is low in Guada. --  The flesh market is in a place called the Rincon del Diablo or Devil's Corner, and occupies part of the outside of the wall which forms the circus, a place where for a few months in the year performs a company

60  Country, -- saddlery, mats, jute, costales or bagging for salt &c. skins, and leather, blankets, leather dresses and a great variety of such goods. --  The Plaza de Venegas, now called de la Independencia, is the Market for Vegetables, fowls, and almost all sorts of kitchen stuffs which are brought from the country, and it is in

63 The state government however gives strikeout: to no encouragement to their Manufacturers and drives the poor people to extremities, more especially the present Government by their arbitrary acts and oppressive laws dispensed in a like unclear manner, which drives them to seek their livelihood in dishonest manners and they too often

62  of equestrians, and to pretty good unclear, and the people seem to prefer this diversion in a great measure to the Bullfights --  The people of Guada. (the lower classes) are industrious, and the place is free of the immense numbers of strikeout leperos which infect Mexico and Puebla. --

rather well formed. -- There was a wedding going on in one of the huts, and the people were dancing and making merry under a shed in front of the door to the music of two instruments intended for a fiddle and a drum. -- This spot is even worse both in heat and vermin, than San Blas, and Santa Ysabel only one league farther on, enjoys a beautiful temperature.  We stopped all night at Sta. Ysabel, and having about an hour before daylight, entered a woody and mountainous  bottom left margin vertical note:  May 13th

64  have recourse to highway robbery, and it is but too notorious that the environs of Guadalra. for a distance of ten leagues on all sides is one of the most dangerous districts in the Country 
upside down lines:
tract, called Los Cuartos, about 7 o'clock, and arrived at the Village of San Lionel at twelve o'clock and after resting, till 4 o'clock, set out, and arrived at Pepic about 8 o'clock. -- In another book I shall be more particular with this last days journey and shall continue

May 10th. --  Left Guada. for San Blas for the purpose of embarking for Guaymas in the Gulf of California. --  Started at 8 o'clock A.M. and proceeded as far as the Pueblitas (3 little groups of Indians huts about 4 leagues from Guada.) in Coach, and then got on horseback. --  The road is infested with robbers, and last night some huts were robbed. --  at strikeout: last eleven, we arrived at the Astillero, 7 leagues a large Venta or Merow?  where a company of the 4th. Dragoons is stationed to keep the robbers in check. --  The road from Guada. to this is a gentle rise all the way and the Country all about completely barren & uncultivated, the hills to the

Vino Mescal from roots of agave americana, produced at Amatitan --  at the plan de Battuneus --  all except a few of the men had wens or tumours in the neck --  attributed to the water  Nebories a valley filled with [[unclear]  from 5 to 50 tons in weight -- 1 mile across

the Pulque and is much smaller.  Tequila is a large town contg. 7000 inhabitants and is beautifully situated strikeout: at th at the end of an extensive plain, which is cut off by an abrupt rise, or I may say precipices on the west. --  The town is well built and has some very large manufactories of Mescal or distilleries. --  The Verduse and Vegetation is most luxuriant, and the climate Warm there being a gentle descent ever since leaving the Astillero and a rivulet running thro' the town supplies water.

2  east are divested of wood or any covering. --  strikeout: At An hour before Sunset we arrived at Amatitan a considerable village distant 8 leagues farther on, but wishing to divide our journey to Tepic into four days we proceeded to Tequila where we arrived late (distant from Amatitan 3 leagues).  Amatitlan is situated in a rocky hollow at the foot of a high hill, and contains about 1000 inhabitants. --  The only produce of the place is Vine Mescal, a strong liquor extracted from the roots of the Agave Americana which however is a different class from that which provides

end of a large lake which extends to the S.E. about 18 leagues, and is about on league to 2 leagues broad. --  this beautiful strikeout sheet of water has not even a single boat or Canoe on it, and it produces a small sort of white fish not very palatable. --  There are some few mines in the neighbourhood (gold & silver) and the town produces a few barrels of Vino Mescal. --  There are some large tracts of cultivated ground in the neighbourhood, producing principally maize. --  After eating breakfast we proceeded to the Guemada, a small Merow distant 3 leagues from La Magdalena. --  our strikeout I road to this is

4  The hill or Cerro de Tequila about 2 miles to the South is about 6000 feet above the plain and completely wooded over.  I have seen this hill from the east of San Antonio to Cerro gordo, 30 leagues to the other side of Guada. on the road from Mexico. --  On leaving Tequila (May 11th.) our road hads zig-zag up the precipice already mentioned, and for about 3 leagues lies along what has now the appearance of the hed of a river running or winding among low hills covered mostly with small shrubs or brushwood.  Five leagues from Tequila is situated most beautifully the town of La Magdalena, at strikeout: on the north W.

ground. --  When Carriages are taken on farther, they are taken to pieces and carried on mens shoulders to El Ocote. --  The country on leaving this is very mountainous and in many places even horses have difficult travelling. --  The scenery is grand and beautiful. --  About sunset we arrived at the Venta and Hacienda de Mochitilte. --  The hacienda has got some well watered spots in Cultivation, and produces sugar, panocha (brown sugar in small cakes) and maize, and brandy

6  strikeout:  along the margin of the la along over the beautiful plain of La Magdalena, which tho' uncultivated I must call beautiful from the circumstance, of its being level and green. --  It is covered with shrubs principally the guisache and nopal.  About a league farther on is the Rancho of El Tequitquite, a few huts. --  Coaches from Guada. can come as far as this by leaving the road for mules and horses in some places and making some round turns to take advantage of the more level

9  rising on its banks to the height of 60 to 100 feet, and sometimes winding along among the shrubs and trees on the more level parts. --  I never have seen scenery which I may call so completely tropical and the immense flocks of parrots and papagayas flying over us and about us strikeout: swif and screaming fearfully in the twilight, gave to the whole the Most Complete appearance of any thing which Can be imagined as wild mountain Scenery

8   extracted from the sugar cane. --  About a league farther on, we began to descend the Barranca de strikeout: Mochifle Mochitilte, and any attempt of mine to describe the grandeur of the scenery would be incapable of giving any idea of the Splendour of it.  We descended an strikeout: per almost perpendicular precipice of about 1500 feet, beautifully winding? after which we proceeded along the bottom of the valley sometimes along the bed of the river which runs through it, sometimes

11  the Vegetation in this delightfull spot is most luxurious. --  There are about 200 inhabitants in the Village, all of whom (with the exception of a few of the men) have wens or swellings in the neck, produced by something in the Water. --  The people have all a sickly hue, and the place is unhealthy, altho' not noted for being so. --  I slept under a large tree which overshadows with its branches three or four houses, and in the morning  left margin vertical note continued from preceding page:  in a direction S.W to N.E. all the way to Neighbourhood  right margin vertical note continued from left margin:  of Durango, and I have seen branches of it as grand

10  between the tropics. --  The moon shone beautifully, any I could not help wishing often that I had some one along with me capable of doing justice to the description. --  About half past eight we arrived at the Plan de Barrancas where we put up for the Night in the largest house in the Village kept by an attentive kind old woman and her two grand daughters. --  The climate is warm but not unsufferable unless when exposed to the Sun, and left margin, vertical note:  This immense barranca or ravine runs from the Pacific

13  preferred sleeping out of doors, and I have never felt the slightest inconvenience from cold at any place between Sn. Blas and Guada. even in November or Feby. which last is the most disagreeable month in the year. --  Leaving the Plan May 12th. a little before Sun rise. we strikeout:  Conti began ascending which we continued to do up a very precipitous track for about 3 hours, and entering on a rather level Country arrived about 11 o'clock at the pretty town of Yztlan

12  found myself considerably bitten by insects and small creeping animals. --  I always prefer sleeping in the open air on these roads, to exposing myself to the fleas and other vermin with which houses are always infested; -- besides the only dangerous animal is the alacran or Scorpion, and these are generally More abundant within doors.  This is now the seventh time I have travelled this road and I have always left margin vertical note continued from note on preceding page:  as at this place, near Colima, and Guadalaxara

15  which is the principal source of wealth to the inhabitants, some of whom are very rich. --  One is surprised to see people dressed in the meanest manner according to our ideas, and keeping small shops where they sell bread, cheese, land candles, and mescal, by the pennyworth, who have in the interiors of their houses massive articles of Silver, and on a pair of shabby looking calzones, two or three dozen of large silver buttons, contrasting strangely with their bare, black legs, which are seen thro' the openings of the

14  distant from the Plan 7 leagues.  We passed the Village of El Ocote consisting merely of a few huts, situated at the head of the Barrancas, near to which is still lying since 1810 one of the large guns brough from SnBlas at the Commencement of the revolution, 3 of which with immense labour arrived at Gauda. --  Yztlan is very beautifully situated and is well built. --  This place unclear about 3000 Mules always employed on the roads, the gains from

tations of Sugar Cane and Maize. --  Fruits in abundance but nothing different from what are produced in Guada. --  The road from Yztlan to Ahuacatlan (distant 3 leagues) lies mostly along the banks of a beautiful and rapid rivulat and is highly picturesque and beautiful, and the Country pretty well cultivated and studded with plantations of Sugar Camotes, chili pepper, maize &c.  Ahuacatlan is a neat town contg. about 8000 inhabitants, & is the head or Cabecana del departmento, or one of the eight divisions of the Canton

16  knees of their breeches, whilst it is not at all uncommon to see women with no other dress than a shift and Calico petticoat, with large gold crosses and relicaerés, and earings and Necklaces of large beautiful pearls. --  The people are generally well informed, but the demon of political dispute has got too much among them. --  Yztan manufactures a considerable quantity of coarse brown earthenware and some Vino Mescal, and has got considerable plan-

19  to all appearance will do very well. --  It is for Extracting brandy from Camotes, plantains brown sugar, &c. and that which has been made has turned out very well. --  But the prejudices of the people I am afraid will prevent their ever making use of brandy that has not at least the name of coming from Catalonia in Spain. --  In the town of Leon, near Guanaxuatl, there was a distillery erected by an other frenchman, who made Spirits every way as good as that imported from France and which

18  Tepic, which again forms one of the eight Cantons into which the state of Calisco is divided for the strikeout purpose of its government. --  It is Certainly on a beautiful model and no doubt would be found to work well with most conscientious men at the head of affairs. --  Ahuacatlan is supported by the same means and produce as Yztlan, and the same remarks apply to each. --  There has been just erected a distillery on a small Scale, by a frenchman, which

the gentleman always makes his customers pay fully double for their fare that other people would charge. --  Leaving Ahuaxatlan about 4 o'clock, our road was thro' a cultivated country for about a leage, when we entered on a woody country for about the same length od road, and about strikeout:  three four leagues from the town the road and country is Such as to defy only? description. --  The Yxiborues is strikeout a tract of about a mile across and
